snippet: Despite warnings from some officials, intelligence experts in Europe see little risk that Islamist militants are hiding among the new arrivals.
abstract: Letter From Europe; number of migrants arriving in Europe continues to rise, heightening concerns over potential rise in crime, unrest and even arrival of Islamic State fighters;  intelligence experts in Germany and neighboring countries say focus should not be on small possibility that jihadists are among migrants but on giving refugees ways to integrate quickly and comfortably into society; argument is that easy transition to new life will make migrants far less vulnerable to manipulation by extremists who are already in Europe.

keywords.value: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
keywords.name: subject

keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
keywords.name: organizations

lead_paragraph: Despite warnings from some officials, intelligence experts in Europe see little risk that Islamist militants are hiding among the new arrivals.

headline.print_headline: As Migrants Settle In, Fears May Be Displaced
headline.main: As Migrants Reach Europe, Fears May Be Misplaced
